bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to [James] Bradley, July 9, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant [James] Bradley, July 9, 1728, to acknowledge a letter of March 9, to cover a bill of lading for tobacco he is shipping on the Welcome, and to note his intention to ship more on the Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, July 9, 1728

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July the 9th: 1728
To Mr. Bradley

div1.p:
The above is a Copy. Yours of the 9th of March is
now come to hand am Sorry to find you Speak so indifferently of
the Market and yet say there was little Tobbo: on hand, I think I may
Adventure to Say you could not have much Supply till the latter end
of last month so that if we might dare hope for any thing you had
time Enough before you to bring the buyers to a better temper,

Herein is a bill of Lading for 15 hogsheads on board
the Welcom Capt: Trice one of my Entire Crops if he had bin in a
Strait for more, I Should have made them up as I Ship in the Carter
for you 20 hogsheads more which Y will go near to be my Quota this year, I am
not well pleased with these lazy Sales, Shall be glad to find they
turn to my Advantage Shall give you no further trouble at present
remain

closer.seg:
Sir
Yor. most humble Servt:—
Trice

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1727 May-1728 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] James Bradley was a London merchant with whom Carter dealt from at least 1723 until his death. As noted in his letter to Bradley of 1727 May 17, Bradley owned the Welcome, but little information about Bradley has been located.

[2] The 140 ton Welcome was owned by London merchant James Bradley to whom Carter would write about her on 1727 May 17. John Trice (Frice) was her captain, 1723-1728. (Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, 154r, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
